posts.author: Moredhel
posts.content:
Hey guys, first post here!

I've recently started playing NWN again, and after fooling around with a monk (lvl 7) and a dualclass (rogue/ranger) I've searched the internet for fun builds. The Rogue/Cleric caught my eye, but I had something a little different in mind. The Rogue/Cleric I mostly saw was based on light armor and the longbow, whereas I want to add rogue for the search/disable trap/lockpick stuff and focus more on frontline combat. I haven't thought it all out yet, and I have no idea which stats should be high, but this is where I am so far @ start (if able, ofcourse):

Human Rogue
STR 14
DEX 11
CON 14
INT 12
WIS 16
CHA 10

not knowing if DEX 11 is enough to start with to deal with traps and locks. I think I would add another lvl of rogue (2), followed by a lvl of cleric (rogue 2, cleric 1) at the end of the prelude. I do know that I will take the Magic and Trickery domains for the cleric part.

Next, and this might be interesting from an rp-based view, is it funky to add a couple of lvls of blackguard (way) later on? I'm just imagining an evil man capable of dealing with traps, locks, the occasional backstab when his pet draws the attention and the ability to buff both himself and his partymembers!

Any thoughts?

Thanks in advance,

Moredhel

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
I second the welcome to you, Moredhel.

I was wondering how far do you actually want to go in learning the ropes of NWN character building. The thing is, you can play the OC with just about ANYTHING and be successful. But, there are other (more challenging and better constructed) modules out there that may require more optimized characters to be conquered successfully.

A Cleric / Rogue / Blackguard with those starting stats will not really be very good. You have 10 Charisma, so Blackguard will only serve you to cost you some feats. You can take Assassin and be a stronger prick if you really want. I'd redo him as a STR build, with the following starting stats:

STR 14
DEX 8
CON 10
INT 14
WIS 16
CHA 14

This way you'll gain +2 to all your saves from Blackguard.

Of course you'd have to start over, but you're only level 4, so it won't be a big loss. If you want to learn more about building a strong character, THIS GUIDE is the place to start.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: The OC and SoU are both supposed to start at level 1. They happen concurrently to two different people. HotU is intended to be played with the character who finished SoU. If you insist on playing all three with the same character (bad idea), the best order is SoU then the OC and then HotU, because the OC will attempt to adjust to your too-high level.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I see, so want a strong RP character then that has it all.

It's like that with everyone's starting character, i too wanted the same.

Well, i could appoint you to a super powerful build that has all the techniques of character building implemented and finishes to a really high power level but i won't do that. You won't need it, not for there.

What i will say to you is some basic principles instead and let you form your character based on these. Because you will enjoy it much more that way, same thing Max said.


A) The OC ends at level 17, the SOU at level 13 and the HoTU at level 27. All values are approximately correct, although you can be one less or one more from that depending on what you will do.


1) You won't be facing a lot of dispels if any at all, so 15 - 17 Cleric levels are in generall enough for everything and maxes out the bonusses for all the buff spells in his list (+5).

2) You won't need more than 4 BG levels, if you want to go for more then the best is to go for 13 at least or else is suboptimal. 13 levels will give you the Epic Vrock.

3) The rest of levels can be filled with Rogue. They won't be enough to take crippling strike for example but they wil give you skills and bonus dice of sneak attack.


B) Keep in mind that the magic levels of the HoTU and even the OC at later levels are high enough that having haste and improved invisibility as domain powers are not essential.

C) Good skills to look for are Persuade, Spellcraft, Tumble, Discipline and Concentration. Some of them are way more useful if you install Tony's AI 1.08 in your override.

D) Good Henchman that fits you alignment is Grimgnaw. Buff him and he can tear everything apart on his own.

E) Take a look at this if you want to enhance your playing experiance ---> http://nwvault.ign.com/View.php?view=Ha ... il&id=7935 and this ---> http://nwvault.ign.com/View.php?view=Po ... 25&id=6117

Don't forget to backup your override folder in case something goes wrong.

F) Look at Max's guide for everything else.


Based on that, make your own decisions and see where they will take you, don't be afraid if you do some small mistake, forge your own character so that you will be pround of him,

and then come to where the real challenges are!

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
You can, but where's the synergy? The thing that makes a toon powerful is exploring features that complement each other for each class. What do Clerics, BGs and Rogues have that complement one another?

Rogue goes well with Assassin, but for level 20 that's not really doable. Clerics need at least 15 levels to be good, BG needs 4 levels do yield its trademark DM / DS, which leaves just one level to take as another class. Rogue with just 1 level is sub-optimal.

I'd have to say no to this request of yours, if anyone else wants to do it, go ahead, I won't. You should really read the guide I suggested to you. It's truly going to help you grow your knowledge of the game, which will make your request stuff that actually has some potential. Focus, man! You have a long way to go.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Moredhel wrote:Yup, for OC/SoU/HoTU

And yup, I want the BG there to be the supreme bastard (I'm currently 2 rogue/2 cleric, chaotic evil) tapping into the cold void of death for more carnage

You don't need BG to roleplay a supreme bastard tapping into the darkest core of evil. You can do that with a cleric - pick your deity, alignment, spell-selection and whatnot. You can even do it with a plain fighter, if you just make the corresponding evil RP choices.
If you want to be cynical about it, the only thing you need to play evil is an avatar that acts evil. And since you want to play evil anyway, the only thing you get from picking BG is a set of class features that only has impact on game mechanics.
Just my two cents...
